text.text: Do I have to complete each section of ERB?

You do not! Users can select which sections, and activities within a section, to undertake. The Plan Your Project section helps you figure out what best meets your needs and capacity. You can revisit this section at any time to make changes to your Project Plan.
How do I save my project?
The project you are working on saves directly within the ERB tool as you work through it. You can also download saved work to your desktop or laptop at any point using My Portfolio.
Will EPA collect any data from me if I use ERB?

No. Once you download the ERB software to your computer, the EPA has no access to it. All the information you enter into ERB is kept within the app. You can decide whether you want to download and save project files to another location on your desktop or laptop.
How much time will it take to go through the ERB process?

The answer depends in part on whether a team to work through ERB has already been established, what the team selects from the menu of activities, whether product deadlines have already been established, and how much time you need to spend building relationships with different local constituencies. If you do all the sections of ERB, a community-engaged, collaborative process for resilience planning could take 8 to 12 months. If you and your team hold one workshop or donâ€™t do extensive data collection for resilience indicators, then it could be done within a few months.
Who can and should use ERB?

The ERB tool is designed to be used in local resilience planning. The primary user group is county, Tribal, or local government agencies tasked with resilience planning. We encourage users to work on a core team that decides which activities to do and coordinates the activities. The core team should include membership from a broad array of agencies, private or non-profit organizations, and other community leaders. Community-based organizations or environmental organizations can be the primary users of ERB, as well as serve on the core team. If a community group takes the lead on using ERB, they might want to consider also inviting representatives from local agencies to aid with implementation of the resilience plan.
